title: Psalms Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who is the author of the prayer in Psalms 17?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:1 states, 'A Prayer of David,' indicating David as the author.

questions.question: What does David ask God to hear in Psalms 17:1?
questions.explanation: David asks God to 'attend unto my cry,' as stated in Psalms 17:1.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:3, when did God prove David's heart?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:3 says, 'Thou hast visited me in the night,' showing that God tested David during the night.

questions.question: In Psalms 17:4, what did David keep himself from by the word of God's lips?
questions.explanation: David says in Psalms 17:4 that by God's word he has kept himself from 'the paths of the destroyer.'

questions.question: What does David ask God to hold up in Psalms 17:5?
questions.explanation: In Psalms 17:5, David asks God to 'Hold up my goings in thy paths.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:6, why does David call upon God?
questions.explanation: David calls upon God 'for thou wilt hear me,' as mentioned in Psalms 17:6.

questions.question: What does David ask God to show in Psalms 17:7?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:7 requests God to show His 'marvellous lovingkindness.'

questions.question: In Psalms 17:8, David asks God to keep him as what?
questions.explanation: David asks God to 'Keep me as the apple of the eye' in Psalms 17:8.

questions.question: Who does David ask God to hide him from in Psalms 17:9?
questions.explanation: David asks for protection from 'the wicked that oppress me' in Psalms 17:9.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:12, David compares his enemies to what kind of animal?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:12 describes enemies as 'like as a lion that is greedy of his prey.'

questions.question: What does David say he will behold in righteousness according to Psalms 17:15?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:15 states, 'I will behold thy face in righteousness.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 17:10 says the wicked speak humbly with their mouths.
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:10 says the wicked 'with their mouth they speak proudly,' not humbly.

questions.question: True or False: David prays that his footsteps may slip in God's paths according to Psalms 17:5.
questions.explanation: David asks God to hold up his goings so 'that my footsteps slip not' in Psalms 17:5.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 17:14, the wicked leave their substance to their children.
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:14 explains the wicked are 'full of children, and leave the rest of their substance to their babes.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 17:8: 'Keep me as the ______ of the eye, hide me under the shadow of thy wings.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:8 says, 'Keep me as the apple of the eye.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with honesty in their speech. Based on Psalms 17, what biblical truth about integrity would you share?
options: God tests the heart and finds no deceit when the mouth does not transgress
It is acceptable to use feigned lips to gain favor
One should avoid prayer when feeling tested
God ignores those who are honest
questions.correctAnswer: God tests the heart and finds no deceit when the mouth does not transgress
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:3 states that God has tested the heart and finds no fault when the mouth is purposed not to transgress. This teaches the value of honesty and integrity in speech and life.

questions.question: How does Psalms 17 teach us about the importance of prayer and trusting God in times of distress?
options: Calling upon God leads to being heard and receiving His saving help
Prayer is unnecessary when enemies surround us
God only hears prayers from the righteous after trials end
One should rely solely on personal strength, not prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Calling upon God leads to being heard and receiving His saving help
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:6-7 emphasizes calling upon God who hears and saves those who trust in Him. This encourages persistent prayer and trust during trials.

questions.question: A believer feels surrounded by adversaries and fears slipping in their walk with God. What encouragement from Psalms 17 would you share?
options: God upholds our steps on His paths so we do not slip
We must rely on our own strength to avoid falling
Enemies always have the upper hand
Avoid the paths God has set to prevent slipping
questions.correctAnswer: God upholds our steps on His paths so we do not slip
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:5 teaches that God holds up our goings in His paths so our footsteps do not slip, reminding believers of God's sustaining power.

questions.question: What does Psalms 17:8-9 teach about God’s protection and care for those who trust Him?
options: God keeps us as the apple of His eye and hides us under His wings from the wicked
Protection is earned by human effort alone
God’s care is only for the strong and mighty
We must face enemies without seeking God’s refuge
questions.correctAnswer: God keeps us as the apple of His eye and hides us under His wings from the wicked
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 use tender imagery to show God’s personal and protective care for those who trust Him, guarding them from evil.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17, how should a believer respond to the proud speech and oppression of the wicked?
options: Trust in God to deliver and disappoint the wicked
Retaliate with pride and harsh words
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God to deliver and disappoint the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:10-13 describe the pride and scheming of the wicked, and the psalmist calls on God to arise and deliver him, teaching trust in God’s justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 17:14 help us understand contentment despite worldly prosperity around us?
options: Worldly people have their portion in life, but true satisfaction comes from God
We should envy those who are prosperous
Fill your belly with treasure to find happiness
questions.correctAnswer: Worldly people have their portion in life, but true satisfaction comes from God
questions.explanation: Verse 14 contrasts worldly men who are full of children and possessions with the psalmist’s trust in God, teaching contentment beyond material wealth.

questions.question: A fellow believer is tempted to compromise their walk to avoid conflict. Based on Psalms 17:1-2, what biblical virtue would you encourage?
options: Pray with sincere lips and seek God’s righteous judgment
Use feigned lips to please others
questions.correctAnswer: Pray with sincere lips and seek God’s righteous judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:1-2 stresses praying without deceit and asking God to judge righteously, encouraging honesty and faithfulness in prayer and life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 17:15, the psalmist expresses hope in seeing God’s likeness after waking from death.
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:15 states the psalmist will behold God’s face in righteousness and be satisfied when he awakes with His likeness, expressing hope in resurrection and eternal fellowship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 17 teach us about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s judgment?
options: God tests the heart and keeps those who remain pure under trial
Avoid all trials by withdrawing from the world
Rely on human wisdom to overcome difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: God tests the heart and keeps those who remain pure under trial
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 6 show God’s testing and listening to the righteous, encouraging endurance and faithfulness during trials.

questions.question: What does Psalms 17:4 teach about obedience to God’s Word in daily living?
options: Keeping God’s word protects from destructive paths
Following worldly ways leads to safety
God’s word is optional for daily decisions
Obedience to God’s word is irrelevant in trials
questions.correctAnswer: Keeping God’s word protects from destructive paths
questions.explanation: Verse 4 explains that by God’s word the psalmist stays from the paths of the destroyer, emphasizing obedience as protective.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by enemies who surround them. Based on Psalms 17, what should they remember about God’s care?
options: God surrounds and protects His people as a shield
Enemies have ultimate control over our lives
We are alone in our struggles
Flee from all confrontations to avoid trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God surrounds and protects His people as a shield
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:9-11 describe enemies surrounding, but God’s protection and deliverance are assured for those who trust Him.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 17 encourages believers to trust human strength over God’s saving hand.
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:7 and 13 affirm that salvation and deliverance come by God’s right hand and sword, not human strength.

questions.question: How does Psalms 17 encourage humility and contentment despite seeing others prosper in this life?
options: Trust in God’s eternal provision rather than earthly wealth
Envy the prosperity of others to motivate yourself
Ignore spiritual matters and seek comfort in riches
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s eternal provision rather than earthly wealth
questions.explanation: Verse 14 contrasts worldly prosperity with God’s treasure, encouraging contentment and trust in God beyond material things.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 17 describes God’s protection as hiding us under the shadow of ___ wings.
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:8 says 'hide me under the shadow of thy wings,' illustrating God’s intimate protection.

questions.question: What biblical principle about parenting and legacy can be drawn from Psalms 17:14?
options: Worldly men leave their substance to their children, but true treasure is with God
Material wealth is the only legacy to leave
Spiritual legacy is unimportant compared to riches
Children should inherit all worldly possessions exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: Worldly men leave their substance to their children, but true treasure is with God
questions.explanation: Verse 14 notes worldly men’s provision for children but contrasts it with God’s hidden treasure, teaching the value of spiritual legacy.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 17.

questions.question: In Psalms 17:1, what is the character of the prayer David presents to the LORD?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:1 states David's prayer 'goeth not out of feigned lips,' highlighting its sincerity and truthfulness.

questions.question: Which metaphor does David use in Psalms 17:8 to express his desire for God's protection?
questions.explanation: David asks God to keep him as 'the apple of the eye' and hide him under His wings, symbolizing intimate protection (Psalms 17:8).

questions.question: In Psalms 17:3, what method does David describe God using to test his heart?
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:3 mentions God's visitation in the night as a means to prove David's heart and integrity.

questions.question: Psalms 17:4 refers to keeping from the paths of the destroyer by relying on what?
questions.explanation: David states he has kept himself from the destroyer's paths 'by the word of thy lips,' emphasizing divine guidance (Psalms 17:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'hold up my goings in thy paths' in Psalms 17:5 within ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It reflects a request for divine stability and guidance
It is a metaphor for agricultural prosperity
It means to build a physical path
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a request for divine stability and guidance
questions.explanation: The phrase in Psalms 17:5 signifies David's desire for God to uphold and steady his steps, a common ancient Near Eastern plea for divine support on life's journey.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:7, what attribute of God is highlighted as marvelous and associated with salvation?
questions.explanation: David asks God to show 'thy marvellous lovingkindness,' associating it with saving those who trust in Him (Psalms 17:7).

questions.question: In Psalms 17:10-11, how are the wicked described in their behavior and posture?
options: Proud in speech and bowing eyes to the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Proud in speech and bowing eyes to the earth
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 describe the wicked as speaking proudly and setting their eyes bowing down to the earth, indicating arrogance and scheming.

questions.question: The imagery of a lion in Psalms 17:12 primarily symbolizes what characteristic of the enemies?
questions.explanation: The lion imagery in Psalms 17:12 highlights the greedy and secretive nature of David's enemies.

questions.question: In Psalms 17:13, what action does David implore the LORD to take against the wicked?
questions.explanation: David asks God to 'Arise, O LORD, disappoint him, cast him down,' calling for divine intervention against adversaries (Psalms 17:13).

questions.question: Psalms 17:14 describes the wicked as 'men of the world' who have what kind of earthly portion?
options: Their portion is in this life, filled with hidden treasure
They are servants of the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Their portion is in this life, filled with hidden treasure
questions.explanation: The wicked are described in Psalms 17:14 as having their portion in this life, with their bellies filled with hidden treasure, indicating earthly wealth and security.

questions.question: What eschatological hope does David express in Psalms 17:15?
options: To behold God's face in righteousness and be satisfied with His likeness upon awakening
To build a temple to the LORD
To reign as king over Israel
To conquer his enemies by force
questions.correctAnswer: To behold God's face in righteousness and be satisfied with His likeness upon awakening
questions.explanation: David anticipates seeing God's face in righteousness and being satisfied with His likeness when he awakes, a foreshadowing of resurrection and eternal communion (Psalms 17:15).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 17:6 contains a confident assertion that God will hear David's call.
questions.explanation: Psalms 17:6 explicitly states David's confidence that God will hear him when he calls.

questions.question: The structure of Psalms 17 reflects a chiastic pattern. Which pair of verses best represent the central plea for God’s protection?
questions.explanation: The central verses (17:8-9) focus on protection imagery, a hallmark of chiastic structure emphasizing God’s guardianship.

questions.question: In light of intertextual connections, the phrase 'hide me under the shadow of thy wings' in Psalms 17:8 is echoed in which New Testament passage emphasizing God's protection?
questions.explanation: Jesus uses similar protective wing imagery in Matthew 23:37, showing the continuity of God's protective care from Psalms to the New Testament.

questions.question: Considering Hebrew word studies, the term translated as 'lovingkindness' in Psalms 17:7 is 'chesed.' What is its theological significance?
options: It signifies covenant loyalty and steadfast love
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies covenant loyalty and steadfast love
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'chesed' (lovingkindness) in Psalms 17:7 conveys God's enduring covenant faithfulness and mercy.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:1, what kind of lips does David claim his prayer does not proceed from?
questions.explanation: In Psalms 17:1, David explicitly states that his prayer goes not out of feigned lips, meaning his prayer is genuine and sincere. This theme of sincerity is consistent with Proverbs 4:23, Matthew 5:8, Romans 12:1, and Hebrews 10:22 which emphasize pure and truthful hearts in worship and prayer.

questions.question: What does David ask God to let come forth from His presence in Psalms 17:2?
questions.explanation: David prays that his sentence, or judgment, might come forth from God's presence, reflecting a desire for divine justice rooted in God's righteousness. This aligns with the biblical teaching on God's righteous judgment in Romans 2:5-6, Psalm 96:13, John 5:22, and 2 Timothy 4:8.

questions.question: In Psalms 17:3, what has God done to David's heart?
questions.explanation: David testifies that God has proved his heart, testing his character and integrity, especially in the night. This theme of God testing the heart is echoed in 1 Samuel 16:7, Jeremiah 17:10, Proverbs 17:3, and 1 Corinthians 4:5, illustrating God's omniscient examination of human motives.

questions.question: What is David's purpose concerning his mouth as stated in Psalms 17:3?
questions.explanation: David declares his resolve that his mouth shall not transgress, indicating a commitment to holiness and truthfulness. This reflects biblical ethics found in Psalm 34:13, James 3:2, Ephesians 4:29, and Proverbs 10:31 which emphasize controlling speech and avoiding sin.

questions.question: How has David avoided the paths of the destroyer according to Psalms 17:4?
options: By the word of God's lips
questions.correctAnswer: By the word of God's lips
questions.explanation: David credits God's word as the means by which he has kept himself from destructive paths, highlighting the protective and guiding power of divine revelation. This is consistent with Psalm 119:105, John 17:17, 2 Timothy 3:16, and Hebrews 4:12 about the Word’s role in sanctification and guidance.

questions.question: What does David request God to hold up in Psalms 17:5?
questions.explanation: David asks God to uphold his movements so that his footsteps do not slip, expressing dependence on divine stability and guidance. This request parallels Psalm 37:23, Proverbs 4:26, Isaiah 40:31, and Philippians 1:6 which speak of God’s sustaining power in the believer’s walk.

questions.question: What reason does David give in Psalms 17:6 for calling upon God?
options: Because he is surrounded by enemies
questions.explanation: David confidently calls on God knowing that He will hear him, demonstrating trust in God's attentive and responsive nature. This trust is echoed in Psalm 34:17, Jeremiah 33:3, 1 John 5:14, and Hebrews 4:16 which affirm God’s readiness to hear and answer prayer.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:7, what attribute of God is David asking to be shown?
questions.explanation: David petitions God to reveal His wonderful lovingkindness, underscoring God's covenant faithfulness and saving love. This attribute is celebrated in Exodus 34:6, Psalm 36:7, Lamentations 3:22, and Titus 3:4 as a defining characteristic of God’s relationship with His people.

questions.question: In Psalms 17:8, David asks God to keep him as what?
questions.explanation: David uses the metaphor of being kept as the apple of God's eye, expressing a desire for divine protection and tender care. This metaphor is further found in Deuteronomy 32:10, Zechariah 2:8, Lamentations 2:18, and 1 Peter 2:9 illustrating God's special regard for His people.

questions.question: What does David request God to hide him under in Psalms 17:8?
questions.explanation: David asks to be hidden under the shadow of God’s wings, a vivid picture of protection and refuge. This imagery appears in Ruth 2:12, Psalm 36:7, Matthew 23:37, and Isaiah 31:5 showing God's sheltering care for His people.

questions.question: Who does David describe as oppressing him in Psalms 17:9?
questions.explanation: David identifies his oppressors as the wicked who surround him, emphasizing the moral nature of his adversaries. This description aligns with Psalm 1:4, Proverbs 4:16, Isaiah 57:20, and Matthew 13:49 which contrast the righteous and the wicked.

questions.question: According to Psalms 17:10, what characterizes the wicked who oppress David?
options: They are inclosed in their own fat and speak proudly
questions.correctAnswer: They are inclosed in their own fat and speak proudly
questions.explanation: David describes the wicked as being fat and proud, a metaphor for self-indulgence and arrogance. This portrayal is consistent with Proverbs 28:25, Isaiah 10:6, Luke 1:51, and James 4:6 which warn against pride and self-sufficiency.

questions.question: What animal imagery does David use in Psalms 17:12 to describe his enemies?
options: A young lion lurking in secret places
questions.correctAnswer: A young lion lurking in secret places
questions.explanation: David compares his enemies to a young lion eagerly seeking prey, illustrating their deadly intent and cunning. This imagery is used similarly in Genesis 49:9, Proverbs 28:15, Hosea 5:14, and 1 Peter 5:8 to describe perilous threats.

questions.question: What does David ask the LORD to do to his enemies in Psalms 17:13?
questions.explanation: David implores God to arise and frustrate the plans of his enemies, delivering him from their wickedness. This plea for divine justice is echoed in Psalm 35:1, Isaiah 54:17, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 6:10 where God vindicates the righteous.

questions.question: How does David describe the wicked men in Psalms 17:14 in relation to their portion in life?
options: They have their portion in this life
They are destined for eternal life
They live in poverty and sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: They have their portion in this life
questions.explanation: David notes that the wicked enjoy their portion in this life, implying their focus on temporal pleasures rather than eternal reward. This concept is reflected in Ecclesiastes 5:15, Luke 16:25, 1 Timothy 6:7, and Hebrews 11:26 contrasting earthly and heavenly values.
